articles.headline: For-Profit Colleges, Long Troubled, See Surge Amid Pandemic
articles.snippet: The coronavirus shutdowns have made online learning more attractive. But students at some schools say they have been taken advantage of.
articles.abstract: The coronavirus shutdowns have made online learning more attractive. But students at some schools say they have been taken advantage of.
articles.lead_paragraph: In March, as colleges and universities shuttered campuses under a nationwide lockdown, Strayer University updated its website with a simple message: “Great things can happen at home.”
articles.byline: By Sarah Butrymowicz and Meredith Kolodner

articles.headline: A Trump Tax Break Is Not Spurring Job Creation, Study Finds
articles.snippet: A report on opportunity zones finds that a tax incentive President Trump credits with revitalizing black communities has mostly helped real estate developers.
articles.abstract: A report on opportunity zones finds that a tax incentive President Trump credits with revitalizing black communities has mostly helped real estate developers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new tax break that President Trump frequently touts as a boon to black Americans and hard-hit communities is spurring relatively little job creation while disproportionately helping high-profit real estate projects and not small businesses, an extensive new study by the Urban Institute has found.

articles.headline: Bolton Says Trump Impeachment Inquiry Missed Other Troubling Episodes
articles.snippet: In his new book, John R. Bolton, the former national security adviser, describes instances when the president sought to halt criminal inquiries. He also says President Trump’s loyalists mocked him behind his back.
articles.abstract: In his new book, John R. Bolton, the former national security adviser, describes instances when the president sought to halt criminal inquiries. He also says President Trump’s loyalists mocked him behind his back.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Read our 5 takeaways from John Bolton’s book.]

articles.headline: Former Atlanta Officer Is Charged With Murder in Shooting of Rayshard Brooks
articles.snippet: The charges come after Mr. Brooks was fatally shot during a confrontation outside of a fast-food restaurant. His family said prosecuting the officer was “the only way to heal some of these wounds.”
articles.abstract: The charges come after Mr. Brooks was fatally shot during a confrontation outside of a fast-food restaurant. His family said prosecuting the officer was “the only way to heal some of these wounds.”
articles.lead_paragraph: [Here’s what you need to know about the death of Rayshard Brooks.]
articles.byline: By Rick Rojas and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: With the Federal Health Megaphone Silent, States Struggle With a Shifting Pandemic
articles.snippet: As state and local governments confront a new wave of coronavirus infections, President Trump is sending mixed messages and Washington’s public health bully pulpit has gone silent.
articles.abstract: As state and local governments confront a new wave of coronavirus infections, President Trump is sending mixed messages and Washington’s public health bully pulpit has gone silent.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government’s leadership in the coronavirus crisis has so faded that state and local health officials have been left to figure out on their own how to handle rising infections and to navigate conflicting signals from the White House.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Noah Weiland, Sarah Mervosh and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: ‘Banking While Black’: How Cashing a Check Can Be a Minefield
articles.snippet: Black customers risk being racially profiled on everyday visits to bank branches. Under federal laws, there is little recourse as long as the banks ultimately complete their transactions.
articles.abstract: Black customers risk being racially profiled on everyday visits to bank branches. Under federal laws, there is little recourse as long as the banks ultimately complete their transactions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Clarice Middleton shook with fear as she stood on the sidewalk outside a Wells Fargo branch in Atlanta one December morning in 2018. Moments earlier, she had tried to cash a $200 check, only to be accused of fraud by three branch employees, who then called 911.

articles.headline: Apple Rejects Facebook’s Gaming App, for at Least the Fifth Time
articles.snippet: Apple has repeatedly denied Facebook’s new Gaming app from appearing in its App Store, citing its own rules.
articles.abstract: Apple has repeatedly denied Facebook’s new Gaming app from appearing in its App Store, citing its own rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: Executives and engineers from Facebook’s games division submitted their new app, Facebook Gaming, to Apple last month for approval to offer it in the iPhone maker’s App Store.

articles.headline: Continued Layoffs Signal an ‘Economic Scarring’
articles.snippet: With new state unemployment claims topping one million for the 13th week, the coronavirus crisis seems to be reaching deeper into the labor market.
articles.abstract: With new state unemployment claims topping one million for the 13th week, the coronavirus crisis seems to be reaching deeper into the labor market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Businesses are reopening after coronavirus shutdowns, governments are easing restrictions, and workers are gradually returning to their jobs. But the layoffs keep coming.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: Trump Can’t Immediately End DACA, Supreme Court Rules
articles.snippet: The program, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, protects people brought to the United States as children by shielding them from deportation and letting them work.
articles.abstract: The program, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, protects people brought to the United States as children by shielding them from deportation and letting them work.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled Thursday that the Trump administration may not immediately proceed with its plan to end a program protecting about 700,000 young immigrants known as Dreamers from deportation, dealing a surprising setback to one of President Trump’s central campaign promises.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Michael D. Shear
